path_1.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_1.feeling: Gripping crime morality play with standout villain work that hits my thriller sweet spot, even if it’s a touch overlong.

path_1.title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (2005)
path_1.feeling: Inventive visuals and whimsy are fun in spurts, but the silliness keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Fargo (1996)
path_1.feeling: Loved the tight crime spiral and dry humor with a satisfying cat-and-mouse momentum.

path_1.title: Fracture (2007)
path_1.feeling: Smart, twisty courtroom chess match that kept me engaged start to finish.

path_1.title: Zeitgeist: The Movie (2007)
path_1.feeling: Conspiracy-laced ideas are provocative and engrossing despite rough edges.

path_1.title: About Time (2013)
path_1.feeling: Gentle time-twist romance with life-lesson warmth that mostly worked for me.

path_1.title: Shutter (2004)
path_1.feeling: Creepy premise and imagery deliver solid chills with a neat reveal.

path_1.title: The Deep House (2021)
path_1.feeling: Cool concept and claustrophobic setting, but it plays more like a gimmick than a knockout.

path_1.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_1.feeling: Mind-bending romance with mood and mystery I enjoyed even when it meanders.

path_1.title: Anon (2018)
path_1.feeling: Near-future surveillance hook is intriguing, though the execution feels a bit flat.

path_1.title: Bad Genius (2017)
path_1.feeling: Clever, high-tension caper energy applied to exams made for a fun thrill.

path_1.title: Till Death (2021)
path_1.feeling: Lean, contained survival thriller that’s tense but fairly straightforward.

path_1.title: Identity (2003)
path_1.feeling: Storm-set whodunit with a twisty hook that scratched my mystery itch.

path_1.title: Dark Knight, The (2008)
path_1.feeling: Still a sharp blend of crime, chaos, and heroics that delivers big moments without being flawless.

path_1.title: Faculty, The (1998)
path_1.feeling: Teen sci-fi horror that’s entertainingly pulpy but not particularly gripping.

path_1.title: Glass (2019)
path_1.feeling: Ambitious crossover with moments I liked, though it never fully lands the punch.

path_1.title: Enter Nowhere (2011)
path_1.feeling: Small, twist-driven mystery that’s engaging in concept if modest in impact.

path_1.title: Evan Almighty (2007)
path_1.feeling: Light, family-friendly goofiness that’s harmless but thin for my tastes.

path_1.title: Mr. Brooks (2007)
path_1.feeling: Psychological cat-and-mouse with a dark split-self angle that I found satisfying.

path_1.title: Orphanage, The (Orfanato, El) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric, emotionally grounded haunting that delivered steady dread.

path_1.title: Wrong Turn (2021)
path_1.feeling: Gritty reboot vibes with a few tense beats, but it didn’t linger.

path_1.title: Equilibrium (2002)
path_1.feeling: Stylized dystopian action with cool ideas that outweigh the clunkier bits.

path_1.title: Doubt (2008)
path_1.feeling: Taut, dialogue-driven drama that kept me uncertain in a good way.

path_1.title: Oxygen (2021)
path_1.feeling: Claustrophobic sci-fi puzzle that kept my attention with its ticking-clock tension.

path_1.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Emotionally affecting prison fable that lingered with me.

path_1.title: Zodiac (2007)
path_1.feeling: Meticulous, slow-burn investigation that engrossed me more than it thrilled.

path_1.title: Marrowbone (2017)
path_1.feeling: Moody, gothic mystery with some chills but limited staying power.

path_1.title: Pianist, The (2002)
path_1.feeling: Powerful survival story that’s harrowing yet deeply human.

path_5.title: Glass (2019)
path_5.feeling: Concept intrigues, but the payoff feels uneven for my thriller tastes.

path_5.feeling: Small, twisty cabin mystery that hooks me on its high-concept turns.

path_5.feeling: Broad, family-friendly farce that isn’t really my lane.

path_5.feeling: Moral ambiguity and quiet pressure kept me engaged despite the straight-drama frame.
